mechanoreception.notes: As marine bivalves living buried in the sand, they likely possess mechanoreceptors to detect vibrations and pressure changes in their environment for predator avoidance and prey detection. Inferred from habitat.

chemoreception.notes: Bivalves use chemoreceptors to detect chemical cues in the water for feeding and reproduction. Inferred from general bivalve biology.

vision.notes: The presence or absence of eyes and visual capabilities in Pharidae is not specified in the provided text. It is unknown whether they have eyespots or more complex visual organs.
